Definition: If you find that the input comment has pornographic materials and activities that offend the public's sense of decency, then classify it as obscene else classify it as non-obscene.

Comment: From very young ages, my 4 kids had first hand visuals of the mortality and devastating trauma caused by guns on game animals. The cute bunny, deer, bear, etc. laying lifeless with a bloody hole in it. And it didn't get up to star in the next movie. Still, to the chagrin of my peers, I never let them point toy guns (or even their fingers) at a human and say "POW!" No squirt gun fights, playing 'Army', 'Cops and Robbers', 'Cowboys and Indians' or Grand Theft Auto type video games (These came out later and as "adults" they played them anyway...). And I screened (to the best of my ability) their intake of movies and TV. Perhaps I was viewed as a hard ass, but, I know first hand that it sucks to be shot. Yet, guns have always been an important tool in my life and I'm not one to throw out a hammer over a black thumbnail. I've kept them handy and I've kept them loaded. If you haven't taken the time to discipline your children before getting a gun, maybe you should get a baseball bat instead.

Comment: A party of five tourists from Nome, accompanied by an old-timer chef, travel by snowmachines to Fairbanks. During the first day goings-on, the tourist are rude and obnoxious. Just then the chef pulls out a revolver and says, "The next complaint will be met with lead." Along the trail the following day, no rude behavior and all is quiet. That night the chef adds more nuggets to the stew. No complaints. Third night, the chef adds more nuggets. Still, no complaints. Fourth night, just outside Fairbanks, the chef asks, "How's the stew?" The tourists reply, "Tastes like moose shit...but good!"

Comment: "I recall in the Sixties ..."  which means, Andrew, you probably remember a time when "women professionals" was an oxymoron.  Me, too...and I distinctly recall the first female announcer and first female newscaster hired by the station in the mid-1970s.   See?  Definite progress, no?

Broadcasting? A profession? "Not the same," doctors, dentists and lawyers might sniff.  Well, many of us did consider it so.  An 8-hour day?  Maybe the morning show guy (who got up at 4:45 to be on the air at 6.) Even he did Saturday remotes.  After a five-day week, I'd roll in for 3-4 hours on a Saturday morning, too, to learn more about my craft from a Vancouver writer who came in part-time.  Man, did I learn.  No extra dough, either.  Just...priceless lessons.  Stayed until 6:30 many nights. The production studios were empty and I could record, edit, play around, discover what was possible... 

Maybe there was one difference from, say, the legal firm.  I had FUN, every single damn day.

Comment: Who gives a crap where the word originated. I spoke about definition, not etymology. 

It's utterly irrelevant where it originated or what it meant when it was created. What matters is what it means today, what people understand when they hear it. Not what it meant once upon a time.

The word "proves"used to mean "to test and show to be false", giving English the expression "the exception that proves the rule" - which literally meant "the exception that shows the rule isn't actually a rule and is not really true".

Over time "proves" lost the meaning of "to show the falsehood of" and only the meaning of "to show it's true" remained, and the proverb survives even though it's modern day meaning makes no sense. It's a kind of bizarre claim that the the rule is true BECAUSE there are exceptions to it.

Words change their meanings over time - and if you don't know the current meaning, you cannot communicate honestly, logically or usefully.

Comment: What did a semen-stained blue dress from the Oval Office have to do with a land deal in Arkansas? After a couple of years of digging, that's all a partisan prosecutor could find against Bill Clinton. 
There's nothing unconstitutional about a prosecutor working an investigation finding evidence of other, related or even unrelated crimes. And of course, it's constitutional to pursue those other crimes. 
Watergate started as the investigation of a burglary and led to related crimes that brought Nixon down. 
Say a judge signs a search warrant based on evidence of an illegal poker game in Joe's basement. The cops come in and find they're not gambling, but there is an ounce of cocaine on the card table. Do they walk out and say: "Darn, too bad the warrant's for illegal gambling. Now we can't make a case for the cocaine."
Same as a prosecutor investigating MAFIA underlings to build a RICO case against the mob boss. She may use a drug case as a means of gaining cooperation.

Comment: Another way to read Zuri Aki's statement is to consider the term "war" more broadly than "civil war".

Hobbes says, “during the time men live without a common Power to keep them all in awe, they are in that condition which is called Warre; and such a warre, as is of every man, against every man” (Leviathan, 1.13).

This is one of the founding myths of society today.  However, it arose half a world away from Hawai`i in the 17th century and was only established here in the mid 19th century.

I can't say what Aki meant, but defining war in Hobbes' sense, rather than the one Kenneth Conklin uses, makes his words less threatening.

Comment: 'We have our own oil'.

There little oil in this area, moreover, not a drop of it will ever come to Canada. The suspicion that 'America fights for Oil' is easily and laughably dismissed by the fact that after the invasion of Iraq - when the USA could have easily taken every last drop of Iraqi Oil - they let the Iraqis set up their on systems, after which, 0% of even the extraction contracts went to US firms, and 0% of the Oil exports went to America. They went to European (i.e. Total), Chinese and Russian Oil companies.

America keeps the oceans free for everyone, and specifically keeps the House of Saud intact - so that everyone has access to Oil - and all other goods.

The Persian/Arab Gulf, which by the way is contentious and only kept open thanks to the US Navy - provides a good chunk of the world it's Oil - only 15% of which goes to the US. Far more Oil passing through the gulf goes to Asia, than to the US.

If you project 'conspiracy' the onus is on you to provide the facts.

Comment: The reasoning of Habs fans who feel M. Bergevin is doing an excellent job on these recent transactions goes something like this: Alzner is an upgrade over Emelin, Drouin is an upgrade over Radulov, and Carey Price is locked up as a Hab, therefore, he has done a fantastic job these past few days.

My thinking is: the Habs were good enough to make the playoffs but not good enough to compete in the playoffs very long because they don't have enough offence, no clutch scorers either. They lost their last two playoff series averaging less than 2 goals/gm. 

Losing Radulov, Beaulieu, and possibly Markov now, takes about 120 points out of a lineup already short on scoring. Replacing with Drouin, Alzner and Hemsky gets you about 70 of those points back. They still do not have a #1 centre, and Plekanec at #2 might be a stretch given his performance last year.

I just don't see how one can say the team is improved over last year. If Markov returns, it will help, somewhat.

Comment: With great respect to all Coupeville and Central Whidbey residents, I think it's "unpatriotic" to move into a naval training area and then demand that the entire nation subsidize your choice by paying for a new outlying field or endanger our troops' safety for your choice. 

That said, I think there are some very real and very legitimate concerns that need to be addressed and mitigation options such as eminent domain, land use policy changes and soundproofing at no cost.  There is a very real similarity between wanting to support my Navy friends' training needs and wanting to support the fenceline communities where both come out ahead.  Such should be the case here, as with Impact Aid repairs.

It's why it's so important to monitor the Town's progress in these comments.  To make sure the comments are thoughtful and welcoming of the patriots defending our rights here at home so we do NOT see another divisive "Boycott Coupeville" movement.  I do NOT want to "party like it's 2013" again!!

Comment: Missing from this story was any mention of John Dellenback's accomplishments representing Oregon's 4th Congressional District from 1964-72. He was a principled, independent thinker among Oregon's moderate Republicans (remember them?) A devout Presbyterian who favored bow ties, Dellenback was admired by constituents of all political persuasions and steadfastly refused to accept any campaign contributions. He was among the many Republicans swept out of office in the wake of the Watergate scandal, losing his seat to Jim Weaver, a liberal Democrat from Eugene. Dellenback later directed the Peace Corps in the Ford administration. In Congress, he crafted legislation establishing the Oregon Dunes National Recreation Area and holding contractors accountable for oil spills from the Alaska pipeline. Eugene is fortunate to have Dellenback's daughter Barbara in our community continuing her father's philanthropic activities.

Comment: I will try to be civil. I am a Vietnam veteran and did receive disparagement at the hands of anti war activists. On two separate occasions, while walking through San Francisco International airport, in full uniform, I was spit on and called a "baby killer". The first time it happened, I was so shocked at what had happened, I did not react for a few seconds, allowing the gentleman time to flee the area. The second time, I did not waste any time and moved to respond immediately. Two marines, in civilian clothing, assisted but the spitter was faster than we were and made good his escape from us. There were a number of occasions where I and others in uniform were called "baby killers" and other pointed names and insults. At the conclusion of the Vietnam conflict, I was in flight deck formation on the USS Ranger, spelling out "Peace with Honor", as we passed under the Golden Gate bridge.

Comment: The 1967 Centennial celebrations under Lester Pearson seem to have been an attempt to reinvent Canada under the Liberals, who regarded themselves as a permanent "natural governing party". This followed the flag introduced under Pearson in 1965.

Just as the distribution of Senate seats is unfair to the West, the adoption of the maple leaf was an artefact of the original merger, appearing for example on the reverse of Victorian coins (i.e. 1876 one-cent piece) strangely as a wreath of maple leafs,-- something to think about as a crafts challenge for those raking leaves next fall in the southern latitudes of Ontario and Québec.   

Given that the maple doesn't grow indigenously over most of Canada's land mass, one of the coniferous species might have been a more practical and perhaps fairer choice,-- unless of course, the West decides to leave in frustration over Trudeau II.

Comment: There is no wage gap between a man and women with the same job and all other things being equal. It is zero.

The broader gap is accounted for by the fact that men and women dominate entirely different sectors of the economy. While sectors dominated by women can pay less, women very often get in exchange: stable daytime hours, a pension (the government workforce is a large majority female for example), extended benefits, physical comfort and safety on the job, fewer injuries both long and short term, fewer workplace deaths, lower career risk and stress (men tend to dominate the more rewarding but far more risky private business world), and on it goes. Women resultingly account for far fewer workplace injuries and deaths, bankruptcies, and suicides than do men. 

Also, does the "gender pay gap" include the vast amount of wealth transferred from men to women nationwide in the form of spousal and child support? 

Addressing the above points would bring some balance to the discussion.

Comment: For the most part, pan handlers of any age don't bother me until they become loud (yelling at times) and rude. But for folks who are not familiar with or ever had to deal with aggressive behavior, it can be somewhat traumatic and in my opinion counterproductive for the homeless, regardless of status. I have been reading about the CCC quite a bit lately and the homeless/unemployed of the 1930's that enrolled for 6 months with the CCC were extremely proud of their service. They were paid $30.00 (worth $539 now) a month and $25.00 had to go back home to their families. But they were fed, clothed, housed, trained to work, and many developed advanced skills. Watching the interviews of the "veterans" of the CCC relaying their experiences reminded me of WWII veterans doing the same. Somehow, I think the answer is somewhere in a program like that. Some may have to go to rehab and some to an infirmary before proceeding on to work training.  Some camps could even be set-up for homeless families.

Comment: Nobody "models" individual storms using GCM's. The granularity is not there, although it's better than it was. I don't think you really get this basic distinction. Predicting individual weather events involves different inputs, data sources and means from the modelling of global circulation by climatologists.  

Climate scientists rarely attribute individual weather events to GW without a great number of caveats and reservations. It was an epoch-making event when Kerry Emmanuel--the dean of hurricane scientists--came right out and said that TS Sandy was as bad as it was because Atlantic waters off NJ were freakishly warm. Likewise, the conclusion that the Syrian droughts that precipitated (sic) the civil war bore global warming fingerprints, an epochal event, and published in the Proceedings.  

I'm not sure I understand what we're arguing about.  There's very little uncertainty in the scientific understanding of the mechanisms of  MMGW. There's much less consensus about impacts.

Comment: No doofus, 
The only reason people who are at risk and high-risk successfully get insurance coverage every single day, is because of the "community rating" and 'guaranteed issue,' provisions of the ACA. 

Prior to that we had the "free markets" for individual insurance and they refused to cover people with preexisting conditions, and would jack up premiums so high when you got sick that you would have to drop coverage. 

Now Ted Cruz wants to allow insurance companies to offer bare bones plans as long as they offer at least one comprehensive plan. That means all the young healthy people will take the cheaper plan, while all the sick people will take the more expensive plan.  All the sick people will be in one plan, with no healthy people to share the cost, causing rates rise. The more rates rise, the more people will drop out, making it EVEN more expensive for those remaining. This will cause the expensive plan to collapse. The classic death spiral.

Trump's original executive order, now frozen by the courts, is indicative of the fate of this one too.  There is no credible national security rationale for it at all.

Comment: The US is not and has never been our "racing partner."  The country is protectionist and has always been protectionist. Some administrations have been more favorable toward bilateral trade, others have not. Mostly the US has not favored bilateral trade within its sphere of influence. How much of the country still believes in slavery is I think, a fair and open question. 
In all cases there are strings attached to bilateral trade as a function of diplomacy, so don't be foolish. 
Moreover, we don't need for the US to be our "biggest racing partner." We need many big partners, and we need to know what we are "racing" for.   Mostly we need a strong domestic economy and ownership of means of production. There isn't a single wealthy country in the modern world that did not build its strength on its domestic economy (whether on the backs of slave labour or another). The US is simply putting the same type of pressure on China that it put on Japan when it ascended from the 60s through the 90s.

It afflicts people who fixate on a part of their identity and use it as a lens through which they see everything. I've seen people flush their careers over it. I think it's happening more now because of search and news algorithms. Not being funny here, dead serious. 

You click on extremely partisan articles about BLM or Trump or Antifa or whatever. The news sites and search engines give you more of the same based on browsing and search history. You start to think that what you're being SHOWN is the "news." Not what you're seeing. What you. Are being. Shown. Subtle difference that drives people to the fringes and makes them think the world is out to get them.

Comment: You know Art, there's nothing evil about Tier 1 PERS; it is what it is. At the time I very easily could have went to work for the state but opted to use my veterans preference and went to work for the fed and I retired last year with 30 years not including military time. 
HR 5714 concerns me though. I have insurance through the FEHB which all federal retires can carry with them into retirement and most do. The problem it seems is that most postal retirees opt out of Medicare, and this resolution requires best business practice which means in order to contain health care costs all retirees, including myself, would be forced to buy into Medicare in order to keep our existing health insurance; cost shifting is all. 
Medicare is absolutely useless in Alaska. What this will do is move tens of thousands of retired postal employees, eligible for VA healthcare, will instead drop their insurance and use the VA. Or better yet some will be eligible for Medicaid.

Comment: Columbus Day has EVERYTHING to do with history: the struggle over the meaning of the past determines how we think of the present.  The discourse of history is always already politicized. Social forms, including nations, that people assume to be normal and natural are really a kind of historical accident. Reality itself is historically contingent.

Complaints about how revisionists are "dividing us" are really just cries of anguish as the assumptions that support certain historically contingent visions of reality are debunked and demystified. In other words, the "divisions" have always been there; it's just that they always benefitted those on one side or the other, and so were assumed to be normal and natural by the beneficiaries.

Any number of examples of this could be adduced: the "discovery of America" by Europeans, the Puritan vision of the "city on a hill" as a model of American nationhood, Manifest Destiny, American exceptionalism, white supremacy, etc.

Comment: It was about 27 years ago.  Someone left a book ‘The Apparitions of Our Lady at Medjugorje’ by Svetoza Kraljevic O.F.M. on my desk at work. I read it and believed it to be a true story. We stopped by her house and I went to her prayer room while my husband was waiting in his truck. I then understood what it meant ‘multitude of angels’ in the bible.

Comment: Sub group analysis is a well known source of spurious findings. Especially when you are breaking up a small sample into 30 different subgroups, it is very likely to cause false positives for some of the subgroups by random chance. Any time a study says they saw a result in one subgroup you should already have some warning bells ringing. Unless the result is reproduced in a proper RCT I would not see any result from subgroup analysis as robust. A scientist with an agenda could "prove" the danger of water. http://statistically-funny.blogspot.co.za/2014/03/if-at-first-you-dont-succeed.html has a good write up with some links to papers on the subject.

From the link

"Here's a study designed to show this risk. The data tossed up significant associations such as: women were more likely to have a cesarean section if they preferred butter over margarine, or blue over black ink."

Review U.S. oil production / price curves over the Carter / Reagan transition, and onwards to the end of the 20th C.  During the latter part of Carter's term, there was open discussion in the Senate about taking the nation back to WWII-style gasoline rationing. RR comes, loosens hidebound rules on domestic oil exploration; production goes up, prices come down - and *continue to decline (in constant dollar terms) clear through 1998*.  During that time, D6, every 1 cent drop in the price of a gallon of gas was $100 million saved by the American economy - *every month*.  Most of that savings went straight into the pockets of the middle class.  :-/  So please spare me tales of unmitigated deprivation.

Comment: At a flat $60k, online tax bracket estimators for federal and Oregon taxes combined (with no deductions at all, which is unlikely) result in a little over $17k in taxes, leaving you with a net of $43k.

$43k/12 months = a little over $3,500/mo.

Your 50/30/20 breakdown results in $1,790 for necessities.

$1,075-ish can go towards "financial obligations."

$716 can go towards "personal choices," meaning your "personal choices" budget is about $24/day.

A truly wonderful, self-reflective follow up article would be a daily "personal choices" diary of how this author (and maybe some volunteer friends) spend their money.  Is she or the average Portlander being responsible in only spending 20% of their net income on "personal choices," and thus justified in complaining about the rest of the equation and state of affairs in Portland proper? “We did not make an assessment of the impact that Russian activities had on the outcome of the 2016 election. Comment: "You seem to be suggesting the opposite?!"

I certainly wouldn't be recommending the opposite, Dave.

I'm providing a bit of context for EE and for the newer pipelines. The way pipelines are designed has implications for integrity and safety down the road. 

Most of the pipelines that were built during the 1940s and 50s were relatively thick-walled. For understandable reasons, companies often experimented with thinner-walled pipe for projects during the late 60s and 70s. 

It appears that companies have concluded that the lower cost of thinner pipe doesn't save money in the long run. So yes, companies are indeed improving on what they've done in the past.

I would have much more confidence in new, thicker-wall, epoxy-coated pipe than I do in decades-old, thin-walled pipe with obsolete coating. I would be fairly confident about the new pipe in EE, TM, Line 3 & 6B and KXL... much less so about the western/legacy part of EE and all of Line 9.

Comment: Klastri, there you go again with the liar accusation.  It is a very sick person who calls everyone with whom they disagree a liar.  No member of Congress can demand access to documents, records and files held by the executive branch in the normal course of their duties.  Select members of Congress who get to see such data do so as members of committees conducting inquiries and investigations of the executive branch. The data they get to see is provided voluntarily by the executive branch upon request or upon issuance of subpoenas for documents or testimony the executive branch may be reluctant to provide.  There also is a thing call “executive privilege” which prevents members of congress from having access to various government records. So you see, Klastri, members of congress do not get to see anything want and anytime they want it.

Comment: Chris, I hear a lot of talk about unceded land.  I don't pretend to have read the treaties or done a survey, so I don't know anything about Parliament Hill.

But if we were to take this thing to its logical conclusion,  everyone on the planet would have to either pack up or pay up.  My ancestors are Irish and Dutch, and  in the case of the Irish, their land was stolen by the British.  I am not familiar  with Dutch history prior to say, 1700 or so, but  my family was teated deplorably by Germany in WWII -- many things were seized, and some of them starved. 

I empathize with First Nations.  But it would be impractical and unfair to give the land back, just as it would be impractical and unfair for me to demand reparations from the British or the Germans.

Let's bolster their chances of success so we can break the tragic cycle of poverty and substance abuse, and support preservation of their culture.  But no more talk of who "owns" the land -- that ship sailed long ago.

Comment: Thanks for this, and now we are getting much closer to agreement! I would only quibble a little with the word "referee".  Referees do not design the rules of the game - they only enforce them. In the Chilean case, relatively successful, it seems that government actually designed the rules, and those rules were very strict - no ownership, only time-bound "concessions", and price controls. In addition, government supported community-based cooperatives managing water under local control in the rural areas - in recognition of the fact that private operators, being profit centres, cannot operate where profits cannot be made.

Comment: If we aim to remove government control of who can contribute to the grid and how much, I am with you. Already after the last Eskom power outages demand has dropped so that Eskom has surplus.  This means that many are switching away from Eskom and some are supplying their own needs.

Comment: I am not partial to Uber (I have no control over the drivers I get and while you don't hear of women assaulted, at least in Canada, by cabbies, it can happen with Uber where there is no real oversight or accreditation for the drivers).  

But AirBnb is fabulous.  The website is great and you choose what you want, though of course you have to read between the lines, and use judgement when selecting your spot.  For example, you don't want to rent a place which run by an 'operator' who does this as a business at multiple sites.  They're likely to be scam artists and you'll not enjoy the experience.

But this business of traumatized neighbourhoods sounds a little overblown, though there's no doubt that some people are jerks and don't behave properly when they use someone's space.  But for the most part, especially in condos and apartment buildings where half the time no one knows anyone, a quiet guest will come and go with no one the wiser.

Comment: The difference is that the model T offered people a transportation alternative that was a tangible improvement to the status quo.

Electric cars currently do not offer the average person a better transportation option in moving from A to B.  They are more expensive and for a good proportion of the North American market unproven reliability issues related to driving range and driving conditions (i.e. extreme cold and heat).   In other words for your average consumer there is little compelling reason to abandon the traditional gasoline or diesel engine.

Not to mention that the "electricheads" apparently seem to think that the electricity required to power these cars comes from pixie dust and the battery and other components are greener than fossil fuel extraction.

China is by far the world's largest C emitter, with its value growing linearly since 2000.  New coal plants continue to come online, air in the country is infamously unbreathable. Comment: Rachael, again you're only looking at the cover pages. Dig a little deeper into the websites you cited. I agree that BLM and the Forest Service were not primarily created to protect wildlife habitat. And yet, without the large acreages set aside for national forests and grasslands and even larger areas managed by the BLM, there would be very little public land available for wildlife, hunting, and wildlife watching in the West. Here's a puzzle for you. Why does the Forest Service manage national grasslands when they have no forests to cut? Watershed and wildlife conservation would be my guess. All of the agencies included in the estimate of public expenses take wildlife management and habitat protection seriously, even if it isn't their main function. And even if you dropped ALL of the wildlife-related work done by the BLM and USFS, the amount of funding provided by nonhunters would still overshadow that by hunters. Stop defending Sen. Kelly. He's not listening to either of us.

Comment: It is shameful that a Port Commissioner would claim, without any justification, that the Port's marinas are subsidized by the Port. Boat Haven's annual revenues have consistently exceeded expenses by 50%. That has translated to a $550,000-600,000 annual net cash flow to the Port after direct costs over the past five years. The Port, however, has elected to use indirect costs of administrative expenses and depreciation to eliminate this surplus. In reality, the Port should address its own glaring increases in administrative expenses, from inflated salaries to the overuse of expensive consultants. It is disingenuous to argue that the Port subsidizes its marinas. Indeed, it is beyond time for the Port to recognize its marina tenants as valued partners in supporting the Port's myriad activities, many which have negative cash flows, through moorage rates.

Comment: Why the head scratching? BMW may be innovative, to some level, but if they're expecting rocketing sales on the i3 the answer is no. The simple answer is that as a pure EV it fails in it's limited range and long recharge time which means it's mainly a city car. One would be severely hamstrung to drive beyond city limits or take a long trip should the need arise. It will be the same for the Chevy Bolt. Neither have a viable alternative to Tesla's Superchargers to at least compete for charging. When coupled as a hybrid with the optional engine, the i3 s no longer an EV and there's better alternatives out there. Also, the i3 the design is limiting for those with growing families. Finally, BMW's reputation holds limited value given 1) their vehicles don't seem to hold up after the warranty expires (4 years), 2) parts tend to take a long time to deliver so the vehicle is unusable for long periods of time and 3) design tends not to be future proofed.

Comment: There is no tax difference between the company paying you  a salary (which is an expense for the business) and paying yourself a dividend, which the company pays tax on, and you paying income tax on the dividend,.  If your company pays you a salary, you can shelter part of that money in an RRSP.  The ship has already sailed for putting money in an RESP.  If your wife and children work in the business (ie: summer job for son) you can pay them a reasonable salary as well.  If what he makes is under the threshold, he pays no tax. You will have a paycheck to show the bank, but they'll probably also want to see the company books.  If you've been sheltering money in the company, the books are probably pretty healthy.  Your company can supply you and employees with health coverage.  If you belong to a chamber of commerce, they have a pretty good plan.
You need to talk to a professional though, and plan out what will work best for you and your company (which are legally separate entities.)

Comment: Sorry to firmly disagree with your point about Toronto not having a housing shortage. In your article you say ..." Don’t blame a lack of housing supply: Despite the claims of many in Toronto’s real estate and development industries, there’s limited evidence of a housing shortage..."

A housing shortage is created by the numbers of buyers ready to buy a home, not necessarily by the total number of people added to the population. That 'additional' demand comes from a much larger segment of the population able to buy real estate. Historically low interest rates have added thousands of potential buyers to the demand side of the equation.

You do not need more people tocreate a shortage. You do create a severe shortage when their ability to carry a larger mortgaged is finaced by basement level mostahge rates.

Comment: Based on some the past 30+ years of Federal governments in Canada there is even more incentive to get laws passed through Parliament this year.  Typically, in a majority government, Parliament is prorogued roughly halfway through the 4-year term in order to start a new session with a fresh Throne speech.

A fairly obvious time to prorogue the government, if the Liberals are following this tradition, would in mid September, just after the summer break and pretty much bang-on the halfway point between Trudeau taking office (Nov. 2015) and the writ being dropped for the next election (August/September 2019?).

Obvious Trudeau and the Liberals are not required to prorogue Parliament in September, but there is a good chance they will.

Comment: The Perkins Loan program, formerly the National Defense Student Loan program was established in 1958 and the stories of those who benefitted form the then 3% student loan interest level are historic.  Mostly used for those going in to the profession of teaching, they had their doors of opportunity opened.  Over the many year the loan interest remained low and rose to a 5% level but with such benefits as teaching in low income areas would provide offsets for the payment of the loan.  That program ws manageable and operated AT the Offices of Financial Aid.  It was a revolving fund and worked well, and default rates were again guarded well by the colleges.  Yes, the economy has changed  but the concept of student aid managed by the institution always worked well and reviews were conducted by the feds to ensure the same.  All concerned need to look at the continuation of this Perkins Loan program for indeed it "did make a diffenrce."  I know, for I was one of the aid officers.

Comment: The reason capital gains are only partly taxed is because part of the apparent gain is the result of inflation and, therefore, no real gain at all. Capital gains were once taxed at 75 %, but this was reduced to 50 %. With inflation as low as it is now, bringing the rate back to 75 % doesn't seem unreasonable.

The reason for the dividend tax credit is that the corporation has already paid income tax. If the shareholders had to pay income tax on the full amount of the dividend, there would be double taxation. The credit is supposed to offset the tax that has already been paid. The foreign tax credit is based on the same principle.

The logic is that "a buck is a buck is a buck" (for the history behind this, see https://www.policyalternatives.ca/publications/commentary/putting-fairness-back-canada%E2%80%99s-tax-system ) and should be taxed at the same rate. It isn't based on the idea that any particular group should be rewarded.

Comment: Augustine and Aquinas opposed legislation against prostitution because such a prohibition would produce great civil discord, not merely a moderate amount of disagreement.  Aquinas followed Augustine in saying that "If you do away with harlots, the world will be convulsed with lust."  Public morality has probably changed since then.  The world would not be "convulsed with lust" if prostitution were prohibited; nowadays, sex is free.  Thus, Augustine's and Aquinas's rationale for prohibiting prostitution disappears.  Almost.  They were also against prohibiting acts that people are hell-bent on committing.  Such prohibitions are futile, and in the end, breed disrespect for the law.   This is not good for the state.

Comment: The Irish Republic has handled this issue rather well.  They have a President, elected by popular vote but understood by all to fill a ceremonial position (but also be responsible for smoothing the way for the selection of a new Government that conforms to democratic, parliamentary conventions where former Government is defeated in the Irelands equivalent of our House of Commons or in a General Election) and otherwise stands apart from partisan politics.  

In short, the role parallels in all aspects that of Canada's Governor General but (a) it's filled by popular election, and (b) the link to the British Monarchy is severed.

Comment: It depends on how you view poverty.

The world bank uses a dollar amount which is a poor measure of poverty and in this sense poverty has generally declined worldwide.  On the other hand a better definition might consider access to clean water, to education, to health care, to food and other basic human needs.

Many of those who exceed the dollar definition of poverty might not consider themselves very well off if they are living and working in an unsafe factory environment with close oversight and limited or no freedom or rights.  

Too many people in developing economies are living in conditions not unlike those experienced in the West during the industrial revolution.  This is both unnecessary and unacceptable.

Comment: Once upon a time, it was thought to be appropriate for members of the opposition party to participate in the presidential administration of the other party.  It was

It's a pity that today's hyper-partisan atmosphere can't tolerate people listening to and cooperating with one another.

Representative Gabbard has shown no public interest in working for the incoming administration.  That she's willing to talk, though, is all to the good and to her great credit. Comment: There are a lot of things you can't do in the military that you can do as a civilian ... like change employers or professions. It's not a fair comparison with the NFL or any other regular job. However, I was in the military and was never told that standing for the anthem was a "requirement". It was just part of the job, and we never thought about it one way or the other.
In fact, I don't know of a job where standing for any reason would be a requirement unless it was part of the job. An NFL player's job is NOT to stand ... it's to play football.
And I can't imagine a job that would require employees to stand at funerals, ship christenings, or inaugurations. That's a real straw man. In fact, I've seen people kneel at funerals, and their bosses never did anything about it.
And I don't see what the word "potential" has to do with anything.

Best,

RTD

Comment: Sorry Lumen, I object vehemently to the attempt to associate oppressive bureaucracy as an inherent component of socialism. That notion arises entirely from the Soviet system that centralized virtually all modes of production; and even then, fairness requires comparing that bureaucracy to the enormous corporate income tax bureaucracy in capitalism (both in government and industry) which the soviets did not have.

There are other ways to socialize production (without the stupidity of soviet centralization) that require no more bureaucracy that in capitalism--a government can be the sole shareholder in an airline or railway or steel plant, and just receive dividends, for instance. 

More importantly, the elements of social economy being considered these days are not the means of production, but rather the provision of social services.

More or less bureaucracy is, I suggest, ultimately a function of government rather than economic system. There is more than one way to skin a cat.

Comment: The bold innovation needed is a fair distribution of the fruits of higher productivity.

The Industrial Revolution, followed by Henry Ford’s groundbreaking assembly line approach, rendered the six day work week a five day one.  With better wages.

This was possible because less human capital was needed to produce higher output.  Business realized that without a reasonably paid workforce, there would be insufficient demand.  

We need to re-learn this lesson.  A burger flipping robot isn’t any good to anyone unless someone can afford to buy the burger.  

When the 1% realizes that they need to share the largesse to make their own lifestyle sustainable, increased leisure time and wages are sure to follow.  Until that time, I think we can expect a certain amount of turmoil.  It’s happening now, with the waves of populism sweeping Europe and the US.

Comment: Treason as a crime is nebulous (almost meaningless) outside a state of open warfare.  During the 1950s, the NP government tried to use a criminal charge of treason to counter the ANC-aligned movements.  After an immensely time-consuming exercise in legal hair-splitting, all the accused were acquitted, essentially for lack of evidence.  
Opposition to the current government at any time, although greeted with horror by the "powers that be", is not a crime (at least not in SA, today).  For the current "state-capture" scenario (I just use the name as a catch-all description), the practical difficulty lies in formulating watertight charges of fraud, etc, that can stand up to legal challenge in court.  For clandestine activities, the gathering of reliable evidence is difficult.

Comment: Five years ago I bought a 1999 Taurus from a co-worker (got it checked out by a local mechanic first, who gave it a clean bill of health) for about $1,800. Three years ago, when my son turned 17, I gave it to him; he'd done most of his learner driving on it, liked it, and found it plenty roomy (at 6' 7", this is an issue). He had fun installing a great new sound system in it, and had to replace a couple of minor things (he bought the parts used and did the work himself), but other than the usual ongoing things (oil, fluids) it's running fine.

When I gave my son the Taurus I bought a 2004 Sorrento from a friend (got it checked out; again, fine) for $2,000. Had to buy new summer tires this year, but again, apart from the usual ongoing things it's been great. 

I chose to buy used for these prices not because I'm poor, but because I'd rather spend my money on other things. If the vehicle is sound and gets me safely from A to B, that's good enough for me.

Comment: First of all, the definition of schism given by Fr. Reese is inaccurate. Code of Canon Law 751: "Schism is the refusal of submission to the Supreme Pontiff or of communion with the members of the Church subject to him." There is no need for illicit ordinations and the setting up of another quasi-Church for there to be a real schism. Even if the results of the four cardinals' intervention/formal correction did not mean canonical schism, you'd still have a very open, ugly, public de-facto schism between those with and those against the pope as we already do. 

More to the point, Fr. Reese makes it clear that he doesn't take Jesus seriously. Three Gospel accounts report the ban on divorce and remarriage as adultery. Jesus' rebuke of the Pharisees is not contextualized by concern over the social/economic difficulties of women put away by husbands (although I'm sure he cared about this). The sole context Jesus gives is the Gen 2 plan for marriage and the avoidance of adultery. Full stop.

Comment: "TD raises home price forecast for Toronto, 20 - 25 percent".

How many similarities are there with Vancouver over recent past years?

In Vancouver, what happened was very simple: The price of houses COMPLETELY, and FOR THE FIRST TIME EVER, decoupled and detached from the local job market, completely separated away from local incomes.

What caused that in Vancouver? It was simply a massive flood of overseas money arriving, buying up house after house and pushing prices to dozens of times the average annual income.

For prices to get that high, as in Vancouver, there has to be an external source of money. Local banks are not giving mortgages to young local workers for dozens of times their local incomes!

Comment: I was part of that generation and also entered a convent at barely 17 -- years before the sexual revolution opened up our culture to the reality that sex did indeed exist outside of the twin-bed marriage shown chastely on TV.  Sex in any context was NEVER mentioned during formation, not once, although rules did exist to prevent "particular friendships" from developing among postulants and novices.  Although we attended classes at a nearby Jesuit seminary, those young men and their priest teachers were held to be ontologically and personally "other," like angels, and thus near perfect.  It was a realm of unreality, an intentional island kept rigorously isolated from the "evil outside world," and served to strengthen the (ridiculous) notion that we and seminarians/priests were at least one step above ordinary people who hadn't received our precious calling.  Given that environment, which lasted as long as 6-8 years, naïveté is guaranteed, but everyone was naive before 1964.

Comment: Initially, I was very sceptical of Edmonton's deal with Katz to get the new arena done. Katz's ham-handed, arrogant negotiating was particularly revolting. 

Now that the new arena is up and operating I accept that the deal is going to be a winner for Edmonton as much as it is a winner for Katz. The 'Ice District' redevelopment is truly spectacular and will spur more and more redevelopment in ever-widening circles in forthcoming years. In 50 years the former wasteland of downtown Edmonton will be completely transformed.

Already it is easy to see a new vibrancy in Edmonton's inner city. This was already beginning pre-Rogers but is now accelerating. In a perverse way the recent U-Haul terrorist incident gave proof to this. Previously, Jasper Ave after midnight was barren and unpopulated. Not so now.

I must also admit that the new arena is really a rather spiffy joint for watching hockey.

Comment: The article is not about AGW. 

You note that China supports the Paris Agreement. This has anything to do with the arguments presented. Guilt by association is not an effective refutation. 'If they believe it to be true it must be wrong'. Not necessarily. Both Trump and Trudeau support the Keystone Pipeline. They could be both right or both wrong. Whether or not a policy is good or bad is not based on the advocates but rather on the arguments presented by the advocates.

There are certainly benefits to carbon. We have, as a civilization, seen a tremendous increase in prosperity, but fossil fuel use as an inherent right of a citizen is clearly not correct. I do not think you would advocate going back to the coal system of heating that lead to the Great London Smog. Smog in California was unacceptable. In both cases governments needed to curtail citizens right to use of carbon. I do not think that these measure were counterproductive. Do you?

Comment: Quite a shame. I thought him a pretty good minister - at least until he backed into a quagmire of his own making. No, I'm not talking about the blind trust, or lack of it. I'm talking about the inept, arrogant way he allowed himself to be cast as the enemy of small business. 

There were actually parts of his tax reform that made sense, such as reining in upper middle income professionals incorporating themselves to pay a lower tax rate than trades people. But the net Morneau cast was bound to capture small entrepreneurs making much less money - and assuming much greater risk. That baby is now out with the bath water.

Adding insult to that injury, Morneau has failed to clear the high bar for personal conduct set by the PM. If Justin is to preserve the credibility of his government, he must - as a minimum - move Morneau to a less sensitive post for the balance of this parliament. Anything less could put a serious dent in Justin's shiny suit of armour.

Comment: It is too easy to consider the sequence of events since BC's May election simply in terms of personal partisan political preferences and thereby fail to see how the constitutional conventions that guide our parliamentary system of Government work so well (especially in contrast to the US congressional system) to aid in the resolution of close or ambiguous election outcomes.

Whereas the US system simply preserves any such deadlock or ambiguity (and thereby stalemate) for 2 or even 4 years, our system forces the leaders of the Parties to try through negotiations to find a stable coalition to govern and if they fail a new election follows.  With very rare exceptions, a stable Government with majority support in the House is the outcome with only a few weeks or a couple of months are needed for the Parties or a new election to sort things out democratically.

Comment: 44 years - 1972.

Like this task force the LeDain Commission also noted that international law prevented legalization of possession of marijuana for recreational uses. The Le Dain Commission stated that the expression "possession" in article 36 of the Single Convention, 1961 had to include possession for personal use and must be criminalized.   

‘It has generally been assumed that "possession" in article 36 includes possession for use as well as possession for the purpose of trafficking. This is a reasonable inference from the terms of article 4, which obliges the parties "to limit exclusively to medical and scientific purposes the production, manufacture, export, import, distribution of, trade in, use and possession of drugs." ...  The prevailing view, however, is that the word "possession" in article 36 includes simple possession for use.’

The LeDain Commission then went onto say if we leave aside international law this is our recommendation - much like the current task force.

This research focuses on what I would call "craft" markets (not long-established, affordable "public" markets) and rightly points out that they are beyond the economic reach of most families. Comment: Hawaii's Curfew Law: A juvenile 15-years-old or younger out in public, must have adult supervision between the hours of 10 p.m. to 4 a.m.
There are exceptions however, and that’s if a Family Court judge permits it, or if the child is on the street for necessity, like returning home their job or school functions.
Officers can call the child’s parents or guardians to make sure they know what is going on.
If a child is in a public place without an adult during the curfew hours, an officer can make an arrest, so it’s important that parents who have children this age, know where their child is at night.

Comment: Polar bears seem to do just fine in their most Southern habitat on land all Summer  along Hudson Bay....Every fall, hundreds of polar bears gather near Churchill, Canada, on Hudson Bay to wait for the sea ice to form.

The bears are part of the Western Hudson Bay population, which is located at the southern edge of the polar bear’s range. Every summer, bears in this population are forced ashore when the bay ice melts. They spend the next few months fasting, living off their fat reserves and conserving energy. When an autumn nip chills the air, they begin migrating north along the coast to Churchill, where the first ice of the season forms. They congregate near Churchill in anticipation of freeze-up and a return to their seal-hunting grounds.

Comment: This is the sort of analysis that validates the skepticism of the likes of me when we hear of the incredible amounts of money swept up by the likes of Google and Facebook. Particularly implausible is the money spent advertising on smartphones where ads are never anything but an irritation. More  investigation of the sort described in this article ought to bring those companies back to the ground.

But by the same token one can question the way advertising money is spent uncritically on TV. Take Canada's only investment/business channel. I watch it quite a bit but some of the shows I do watch consistently have such a god-awful host that I record them, then Fast Forward through  skipping all but a few minutes (sometimes 0) of content that is of particular interest to me. Do advertisers take these aspects into consideration when they hire specialized companies to allocate their budget to different outlets?

Comment: Hmm, not sure that's true.  Tough to get a true figure on what First Nations annual costs are for tax-payers, but based upon findings from some who've spent much more time than I in attempting to discover the magic number, it's likely around $10 billion a year.  Yeah: BILLION, when all programs, special assistance aid and other items are added in. 

So, that is still way, way more than the cost for a one-shot 30,000 Syrian refugee influx, and a whole lot more than the 3 Billion we provided in humanitarian aid to Afghanistan and Syria over a 5-year period. (Source: Government of Canada)

Now, if you want to talk Bigger Bang for the Bucks, I'd likely put the refugee program ahead of First Nations, (and certainly Afgranistan/Syria aid) although it'll be a generation before Canada sees a "return" from refugees. There is very little "return" on the dollars we contribute to First Nations, while the demands for more are increasing all the time.

Comment: As a veterinarian that specializes in canine and equine sports medicine, as well as an Iditarod Trail veterinarian, I can tell you that there can be functional abnormalities in nerve, heart and electrolyte metabolism that can happen suddenly and do not leave signs after the damage is done. Comment: I really feel that you have no idea what you are talking about.  "The science to determine these things is much simpler than the science needed to put a man on the moon or a lander on mars".  It's the other way around.  Calculating the trajectory of a spacecraft to coincide  with an object in space that has known velocities and orbital patterns is a much easier feat than trying to reliably predict cause and effect in a climate system as dynamic as the earth's.  

There are 22 active weather satellites orbiting earth at this moment, weather stations all over the globe, weather buoys, and who knows how many scientists probing every corner of the earth.  Meanwhile the first moon lander had less computing power than my angry birds app and they managed to pull it off.

Comment: I suspect it was picked largely to kill cannabis. Most recreational users have a residual level of 2-3 ng, so the studies "Crash victims test positive THC" simply measure the rate of cannabis use in population.  

Real-world driving studies on THC impairment (DOT-HS-808-78) show that THC levels in the 10-20 ng/ml range "do not impair driving ability to the same extent as a (BAC) of 0.04 %". THC impairment drops quickly in the hour  or its less than a beer.

From 2005 until 2016,  Colorado's highway fatality rate has remained constant, and the serious injury rate has decreased.  Unfortunately, the press focused on the "Spike in Highway Fatalities", and forgot to mention the population and driving rates also increased. 

When you can't tell if a person on Cannabis is impaired , they probably aren't impaired. Booze and pills are the real killers.
